CHRIS: All right, so
we'll get started again. And as I said, we're
going to provide you with a quick tour of both some
basic concepts in recording

audio, as well as the
specifics of our audio package. And then we're hoping that we
have about an hour at the end

to play with both the camera and
the audio equipment together. So this is a very,
very cursory look

at some basic audio concepts. And there are a couple of
really, really simple-sounding
rules that I want to emphasize.

And this is the first one. Sometimes sound is more
important than picture. And someone like
Vertov would probably

have a heart attack if he
heard someone involved in film say that.

Because of course,
the Kino-Eye is God. But this is actually true.

And if you think
about it, if you got the interview of a lifetime
or got to spend half an hour

filming someone who
you just were never going to be able to
film again and you had

a choice between
getting the audio and the video, which
would you pick?
AUDIENCE: Audio. Because s CHRIS: Sorry? AUDIENCE: Audio. CHRIS: Yeah.

Because if you don't have-- I mean, of course, it depends. If you're filming the
labor in the field

and you're not talking
about specific individuals, if you're talking about
vast social groups,

then the image,
of course, is all. And image is
extraordinarily important. I'm not, of course,
diminishing that.

But if you get to spend
15 minutes or five minutes

asking Barack Obama
what he thinks about topic X of
your documentary and you don't have any
audio, that was that.

If you don't have any picture,
you can still use the audio, and you can find a
way to make it work.

So audio is extremely important. And the only reason
I'm emphasizing that is that it sometimes
gets short shrift when

people are thinking
about film or they're learning to make films.

There's sort of an
assumption that it can take care of itself, that
I'm going to get familiar with the camera and
it's digital audio,

it's really great
quality, it'll be fine. It's its own art form.

And it is complex. And it's definitely
worth knowing the basics.

So this is just a quick
look at our equipment we are filming with the Sony
A1U HDV camcorder, which

records digital audio
at a sample rate of 48K and a bit depth of
16, or 16-bit audio.

And we're going to talk
a little bit about what that means in a minute. But for now, it's worth
just noting and remembering

that that is the format
that you're recording in. It becomes very
important when you're editing in post-production
to know what

the format of your audio is. And that's it. We can film to two channels,
left and right, which

means that you
can record stereo, or you can use them
as separate tracks with two microphones recording
completely different things.

So two channels
does not necessarily mean that it's
automatically stereo. It depends on how you set it up.

We have two microphones
in our kits. One is a lavalier
microphone, which is like the one
I'm wearing here,

something you can
clip to a person. Ours are not wireless,
unfortunately, like the one I'm
wearing right now.

They are omnidirectional
microphones. And we'll talk in a minute
about what that means. We have one shotgun
microphone, which is a longer,

larger, thinner microphone. You'll see it in a minute. And that is what we call a
supercardioid microphone.

And again, we'll talk
about that in a minute. So what does
omnidirectional mean?

As I said, our lavalier
are omnidirectional mics. What that means is that their
pattern, the pattern of pickup,

the pattern that they
record, goes out equally in all directions. So if you see in this
picture, the microphone

head there is in the
center of the frame. Everything equally
in all directions

is recorded at a similar level. So if you're two feet away
to the left and two feet away

to the right and two feet
above and two feet below, it's all the same. So you can move further away
from the microphone and closer.

But changing the orientation
of the microphone is not going to
change your recording.

So again, it's a great
microphone to put on a person. Not all lavalier microphones
are omnidirectional, by the way,

but ours are. And it's kind of a set it
and forget it kind of mic.

You put it there. You set it down. And it records what's around
it based on how far away and how loud the noise is.

Now, the disadvantage of an
omnidirectional microphone is that it picks up everything. So if I'm here talking to
you with an omnidirectional

microphone on and there's a car
or a truck idling over here, the microphone is
going to pick up

that sound equally to the
sound that I'm making here. It doesn't distinguish.

It's just whatever is in
my field, I'm recording. And that's why we have
other patterns that we

use in other situations. The boom-- the boom microphone--
is a supercardioid pattern.

And you can see that's a
very different pattern. It's primarily focused to
the front of the microphone.

So you're going
to record what you point at much more strongly
than anything to the side.

You see how it drops off
on the left and the right, and then there's a little bit
of pickup in the back, as well?

But it's much narrower
and not as intense. So this is really
great for a situation

where you have a lot
of external noise. So if you were
interviewing somebody and there's a truck idling just
to the left or to the right,

if you point the
microphone right at them and get a very good
read on their mouth

and you're close enough, you
can actually really, really significantly
reduce the recording

of the truck that's idling. So as you can see, especially
in documentary film,

this is a really important
microphone to have. Because you can't always control
the situation that you're

recording your audio in. So in a really great audio
recording situation where

the room is pretty quiet-- this is not a bad room-- an omnidirectional can
solve a lot of problems

because you don't have
to worry about it, and you don't have to have
somebody actually operating

the microphone or the boom. But in a difficult
situation or a situation that's very fluid, where
people are moving around,

this can really save you. The downside, of
course, is that you have to keep the
microphone pointed at what

you're trying to record. And that means that you
need somebody doing that. It's very hard for you--

well, really impossible--
for you as a cameraperson to also be a boom operator.

Because that takes two
hands, and you're going to-- and it takes two brains. And it's a completely
different thought process.

So this really
requires, especially in a situation where maybe
somebody's moving around a lot

or you're going from one
thing to another, to have a separate person
worrying about the audio,

worrying about the recording,
what the microphone's picking up, listening very carefully.

So it's a really great
thing to have in your kit, but it adds to the
complexity of shooting.

And you'll see that in a minute
when we pull out the equipment.

So what's the objective? Simply put, get the
cleanest recording you

can at the best level you can. The cleanest recording
means the one that is the most focused on
the audio you want to record.

Dennis in the back
is recording me. He wants to get a clean
level of my voice. It sounds simple, but it
can get extremely difficult

and extremely complicated in a-- what's that? AUDIENCE: No, I was just
pointing because there's lots of sound [INAUDIBLE].

CHRIS: Oh, yeah. So I don't know. Dennis, I'm sure, is
getting a good level because the microphone's
right by me, and that is dropping away.

But absolutely. If I decided to climb up
next to the air ducts, Dennis would not be happy.

DENNIS: Or if I turn up the
camera mic to hear a question. CHRIS: Exactly. Right. So he's got a microphone
mounted on the camera, which

he can use-- he can turn up to
record you guys. But he is also, then, starting
to record the room sound.

So get the cleanest
recording you can at the best level you can. And we're going to talk a little
bit about recording levels

and what are good recording
levels here in a minute. So how do you do that?

Well, there are a lot of
things you can change. Again, if you go back
to the first class, when we talk about what
we were calling

the plastic elements of film,
sound is one of those elements. And within sound, there are
an infinite number of things

you can affect, you can
impact, you can change, in order to improve the
audio that you record.

First, of course, is the
microphone you choose. In our case, we have two. We have the
omnidirectional lavalier,

which is going to be
exactly the right mic in a lot of situations. We have the
supercardioid boom, which

will be the right mic
for other situations. The position of the microphone. How close is it to your subject?

The lavalier I'm wearing right
now is really close to me. It's really close to my mouth. So it's picking up
a really good level.

Maybe it could be too good. What if it's overmodulating? What if I'm distorting
because I'm too loud?

Well, Dennis will hopefully
change that at the camera. But another way
to change it would

be to move the microphone back. So if you're booming,
for instance, and someone was booming
me with a microphone

and I started yelling, you
could pull the microphone away, and that would change the level.

You could obviously
change the position and affect who you record. If we were having a
conversation in this class

and someone was booming
the whole class, they could focus
on me when I talk. Then they could shift
to Dave when he talks,

shift to one of
you when you talk. And you're changing,
of course, the level of each of those things.

So what else can you change? The location. Sometimes you can change that. So what I mean by that is let's
say you arrange that interview

with Barack Obama. And it happens to be the day
that they're redoing the Rose

Garden, and there are
jackhammers and dumpsters in the Rose Garden.

Well, what can
you do about that? Maybe you can
change the location to the other side
of the White House.

Maybe you can't. But you can try,
and you should try. If you find yourself
in a situation

where the audio recording
is just undoable, you need to be proactive about
it and try to make a change.

And sometimes there's a
feeling of, oh, my gosh,

I can't do anything about this. I can't bother this
person to change, to change to a different
office or change the location.

But sometimes you have to force
yourself to speak up and do it.

So what else can you change? The recording level
on the camera. The cameras have adjustable
input recording levels

so that, depending on where
the microphone is placed, how loud the sound is,
how loud the person is or whatever it is
you're recording,

you can adjust the signal
that comes into the camera.

You can add a filter. But you should be
careful about that. The microphones and, I
believe, the camera, as well,

both have filters that
allow you to filter out certain frequencies. And I think they're
pretty much in all cases

low cut frequencies. So they're designed to
filter out truck sounds.

Like if there's a truck idling
that's a very low-frequency sound, it will cut it.

The reason you should be
careful is that, again, once you've recorded it that
way, it's recorded that way. You've lost those frequencies.

And it's generally better to do
that in post-production, to do that in editing, where
you have control.

You have the full range
of your recording, and then you can fix it later.

But in some cases, some really
significantly bad cases, you may want to
use those filters.

And then, of course,
finally, your own technique. You can do a better job
of placing the microphone,

do a better job of choosing
the microphone, and so on.

So digital audio-- what is it? As I said, we have a sample rate
of 48K and a bit depth of 16.

And that is sometimes-- less so now as CDs
disappear from the scene--

but referred to as
CD-quality audio-- actually, slightly better.

What that means, however,
is not that your audio will be pristine. Because it all depends
on the recording.

It doesn't necessarily depend
on the technical quality of your signal.

So in other words, you can
get pristine CD-quality audio of that truck idling
next to your person,

and it still sucks. And that's something that
you run into a lot of times.

When people are
starting out, they say, but the audio is digital,
and it's very high quality. It's going to be great.

I don't really need
to worry about it. Again, it all
depends on what you

put in front of the microphone,
just like it depends on what you put in front of the camera.

So I want to just mention
quickly what the sample rate is and what the bit depth is.

Sound, most of us, I'm
sure, know sounds are waves. They are waves of compressed
air that travel through the air.

And how much
compression there is and how fast they are,
how short the wave is,

is what determines the loudness
and the frequency of the sound. So if you think about,
well, how would you

translate that into
digital terms, what you do is take a sample. And the number of
samples per second

is what the sample rate is. So this wave is broken down
into lots of little slices.

And the more slices you
have, the more smooth this plot is going to be.

So slice, slice, slice, slice,
slice, or a lot fewer slices. There would be a lot of
jagged edges up here.

So higher numbers are better. That's kind of a very
simple way to look at it. 48K is very good sample rate.

CDs are 44.1. 48 is pretty much at the
level where human ears are not

going to hear any kind of
digitalness in the audio.
So that's the sample rate. What's the bit depth?

So the bit depth is the
opposite side of the grid. That's the number of bits
recorded in each sample.

So if you think about
it, this is our sample, if we had vertical
lines going here.

The bit depth is the other side. It's the horizontal
lines going up. So if you have 16
bits, what that means

is there are 16
levels in each sample. And if we had the
vertical lines here,

you would then suddenly see
that each one of these is a bit. Each little box is a bit.

So again, higher
numbers are better because you're slicing
it much more this way and slicing it this way.

So the more you slice
it, the more you end up with a very smooth path. You see here we have this
digital, blocky path.

But it's emulating this very
smooth wave of the sound. So 16-bit audio is, again,
a very, very high quality.

24-bit audio is, at this
point, what they generally use to record professionally
if you're mastering

music or something like that. But 16-bit is
extremely high quality.

So digital levels. And this is-- you can
actually forget everything that I just said to you.

I think it's worth knowing,
but it's not necessarily anything you really
need to think about on a day-to-day
basis when you're

recording audio for video. But it's just nice to
know when somebody says,

oh, that's 48K audio, you know
what they're talking about. This, however, is really, really
crucial in recording audio.

And this is a digital meter. And it's what you really have to
live by when you're recording.

And Dave will show
you in a minute how to see the
meter on the camera.

You have, basically,
in digital meters,

there's generally
a readout of dB-- decibels-- from minus 30 to 0.

And 0, if some of
you who know anything about analog recording, 0 is
kind of a really good place

to be in analog recording. It's a really bad place to
be in digital recording.

What you want to be-- you want your average level
to be between minus 20 and minus 12 and your peaks
around minus 10, at most

around minus 6. Because, basically,
when you get to zero, that's when you start
getting distortion.

That's the top end of
what can be recorded. And after that, it's all gone.

And you're just
distorting your signal. So you don't want to
get too close to zero.

And similarly, if you start
getting below minus 20, your signal is so low
that the background

is going to start coming up. And there's very
little difference between what you're
actually trying to record and what the background is.

So the key is really to stay
between minus 20 and minus 12. But peaking a little higher
than that is totally fine.

By peaking, I mean I'm
talking very softly, and then I say, (LOUDLY)
Dave, where's the camera?

So when I peak,
when I speak louder,

that would be fine to be
going up towards minus 6. I don't know where
I went there, Dave.

Dennis, sorry. [CHUCKLES] So anyway, this
is one of the crucial things

to remember, far more than the
bitrate or the sample rate.

And this is the second rule. If it sounds bad,
it probably is bad. And what I mean by
that is that far

beyond the microphones
or the cables or the camera or the
filters or anything

you can do in post-production,
the most important tool you have when you're
recording audio are your ears.

Your ears are really incredible. You just have to learn how
to listen and to trust them.

So if you're hearing bad
sound in the headphones, if you're hearing a
lot of interference

or a lot of background
noise, pay attention to that. Don't just kind of
accept it like, oh, yeah,

I hear what's going on. Listen to what else is
going on and then work

on trying to fix it,
either by, as I said, you can change the microphone
or change the location, change the position
of the microphone.

Try to solve your problems. But your ears are what
are going to tell you that you have a problem.

So if it sounds bad,
it probably is bad. That's it.

AUDIENCE: Just one example
that if it sounds bad, it probably is. One of the [INAUDIBLE] just
made that they helped out with,

which was about the Three
Mile Island nuclear plant, and we had a lot of interviews
with people in their kitchens.

And one of the things that came
up was the refrigerator hum. And you feel horrible.

I mean, it's this
documentary situation. And you're talking to people. But you keep hearing
this refrigerator hum in the background.

And you don't want these
people to turn off the fridge. But on the other hand,
if you don't do it, then you have this buzz
throughout the recording

that you end up can't
using it afterwards. So we had to become
bold about asking people

and, very apologetically,
look, if you don't mind, can we just turn off your
fridge for a little bit? Because we couldn't
get the sound otherwise

So those are the kind of
examples of things where, even if you might feel
very awkward about it, sometimes you have to do it.

Because people will be more--
they might be a little taken aback, but they're going to be
far more irritated if they give

you two hours of their
lives for an interview, and then all of it's
unusable because you didn't get the sound right. So those are the
instances where you

have to be bold,
even if you might be feeling somewhat shy about it. But again, listening to
your ears and trusting it.

And sometimes, you just have to
like, well, I'm not getting it. We've got to do something else. Or if there's airplane
noise overhead,

sometimes you're just losing it. And you have to acknowledge that
and not think like, oh, it's going to be a [INAUDIBLE].

CHRIS: And one thing, as Dave
goes through the audio package, to remember is that there
are headphone volume--

there's a headphone volume
control on the camera. But that's not the same as
the audio recording volume.

So sometimes what people do
is the sound is very faint,

or there's a problem. They turn up the
headphone volume. And they go, OK,
that's much better. But it's not necessarily
better at all.

You have to look at the
level that is being recorded. And you have to get the
headphone volume to the point where you can actually
hear what you're recording

and assess it and see
if there's a problem.  So with that, I guess we'll
break out an audio kit.

DAVE: If you guys could
just open up the camera kit and take out the cameras.

And put the battery
in the camera. And turn that sucker on.

And again, there
are three options. Make sure that
the green light is at the very top
where it says Tape
when you're turning the knob.

Again, green light at the
very top where it says Tape.

of your camera kits, we have the audio

this piece. AUDIENCE: Do you want

If you guys could fit that

And I'm sorry. This little extension

that's going to be going

CHRIS: Your bag's in

So again, once it's slid on,

Cool. Now, once that's slid on

right behind the adapter. And take this little chute

Again, use the arrow

the arrow that's

in the little hatch door. So again, the arrow
that's on the bottom,

match it up with the arrow
that's within the actual door there.

And when it's in,
slide it forward until you feel it click.

This is the actual
connection to the camera. So if this is not
inserted correctly and you don't hear
it click, then you're

not going to be
recording any sound, at least from these
microphones that you're using the adapter for.

Everybody good? Again, make sure this
is tight, please.

Cool. Now, before we actually
connect the mics, on the left-hand
side of this adapter,

you'll see a number of switches. It's very important that you
turn the switches on correctly.

We're going to use the lab mic,
as well, two separate channels? CHRIS: Yeah, I think we should
go through everything, yeah.

DAVE: OK. The one at the very front,
where it says recording channel

select, if you're going to
go with just one microphone, make sure it's on-- it's
kind of counterintuitive--

if you're using
just one microphone, make sure that the switch is
on channel 1 and channel 2.

Because what it's going to do is
if you're using one microphone, it's going to route it
to both those channels.

So you have the option of
stereo when you import it. If you're using two microphones,
two separate channels,

make sure this switch right
here is switched to channel 1.

It's counterintuitive, I know. AUDIENCE: Can you repeat that? DAVE: If you're using
two separate microphones,

make sure this front
switch is on channel 1. Because what it's
going to do is it's

going to make sure that that
first microphone is routed to channel 1 instead
of both channels

so that you will actually

the same one?
Or when I [INAUDIBLE] DAVE: Yeah.

There are two jacks. And you're going to have
two separate lines for two separate mics. What you're holding
right there--

actually, if you want to
get a shot of this, Dennis. Can I use your name on camera?

I just want to-- this one right here does
not have a battery in it,

the one that's
included in the kit. So if, for any
reason, you decide to use this microphone that's
included in the camera kit,

make sure that the plus 48
volts is switched to on.

You only put that on on if
your microphone does not have a battery.

That way, the electricity will
run through the camera battery. But the good mics
that we're going

to use in the audio packet, they
should have batteries in there that you actually put
into the microphone.

If you put plus 48
volts and you have a battery in your
microphone, you're

going to have some
pretty loud sound. CHRIS: A lot of distortion. DAVE: A lot of distortion, yeah.

CHRIS: So this was a big issue
last time we taught this class. So again, if you're going
to use the microphones

in the audio kit,
switch that to off. And just make sure that you have
batteries in your microphones,

as well. We'll get to that in a minute. DAVE: Which, again,
when you actually have your headphones connected
and you see the levels,

you're going to be able
to check that, anyway.

For your input
level, you see where, on the actual left side
of the audio adapter, it's divided into two
sections, input 1 and input 2?

For both input 1 and input
2, where it says input level, make sure you have the middle
selection, which says mic.

So for input 1, make
sure that's set to mic.

For input 2, where
it says input level, make sure that's
set to mic, as well.

That's just telling your adapter
that you're using a microphone. The only reason you
really set it to line,

which is the top option,
is if you're using a mixer or if you're going through
some outside source.

A mixer allows you to have
more than two channels, and you can actually control
the volume and stuff like that.

We don't have a mixer. If you have one at home,
propping up your coffee table or something, you can
bring that in and use that.

So it's very important that you
have input level set to mic. If you have the very
bottom one, mic attenuated,

that's going to cut
out some of your sound. So don't set it to that.

Set it to the middle one, mic. Again-- we kind of went
over this already-- for both input 1 and input 2,
where it says plus 48 volts,

make sure that's set to off
for both input 1 and input 2.

Do you want me to point to it? CHRIS: I've got it in
the shot right now. DAVE: OK, cool.

On the back of the
adapter, you'll see there are two
low cut filters.
These are for both mics. Make sure these are set to off.

Because, again, what
low cut filters do is they cut out that deeper,
the deeper frequencies.

And you probably
don't want to do that, especially in an interview. Because the human voice,
you need that to-- it's going to sound very
thin if you have that on.

So make sure that, again,
the low cut filters are both set to off on the
very back of the audio adapter.

And again, like Chris was
saying, if you do need to--

say you want to simulate a
telephone call or a telephone conversation, that's
something you can do in post. You just take out the low
frequency and the high,

and you just boost the middle. You can do something
like that in post. You want to get as much of
a dynamic range as possible

when you're in the
field, recording stuff.

OK, everybody there? All right. Now, if you guys could
break out those sound bags,
the sound kits.
Yeah, I'll put this here.

The first thing we will do is
go over the shotgun microphone. This is a supercardioid
microphone.

So if everybody could-- it
should be buried in almost all the packets-- I think all of them-- in the
front of the two big pockets.
[CHATTER]

OK, everybody got it? If you could, at the very
back, if you twist the back,

it should twist open. Make sure there is a AA
battery inside the microphone.
If there isn't, let me know.

And then you can
